title: V2O3 Thin Film Insulator-Metal Transition Characterization Using Cryogenic 4D-STEM
content: Vanadium trioxide (V2O3) is a Mott insulator experiencing an insulator-metal transition (IMT) at around 150 K. The IMT is associated with a structural phase transition from the insulating monoclinic crystal structure to the metallic corundum one. The IMT can also be triggered electrically (resistive switching) and can be used for cryogenic neuromorphic application as spiking neurons. It is well known that mechanical stress impacts the IMT by changing the temperature of the transition and the threshold voltage [1]. By engineering the strain in the V2O3 material it is therefore possible to alter the behavior of the material to design specific devices. Various methods exist to mechanically stress the V2O3 material, such as chemical doping, heteroepitaxy or lateral stressors with different strain profiles in the material.
